title: 104_hr1416
content: The Act may be cited as the "Torture Victims Relief Act of 1995". The Congress finds that torture creates fear and insecurity, destroys individuals and society, and is used by repressive governments to suppress democracy. Torture victims face long-term physical and psychological threats, with perpetrators often not held accountable. Torture victims and their caregivers need protection from reprisals. Many refugees in the US have been tortured and need prompt asylum consideration. Survivors should receive rehabilitation services to integrate into society. Democratic cultures require addressing torture survivors' needs. The development of a treatment movement for torture survivors has created new opportunities for action by the United States and other nations to oppose state-sponsored acts of torture. There is a need for a comprehensive strategy to protect and support torture victims and their treatment providers as part of the overall objective of eliminating torture. By acting to heal the survivors of torture and protect their families, the United States can move to defeat the actions of torturers. The United States has ratified the Convention Against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman, or Degrading Treatment. The United States has ratified the Convention Against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman, or Degrading Treatment, but has not implemented all provisions of the convention. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "torture" in this Act refers to intentionally inflicting severe pain or suffering, whether physical or mental, on a person for purposes such as obtaining information, punishment, intimidation, or discrimination, by a public official or someone acting in an official capacity. It excludes pain or suffering from lawful sanctions. The terms "substantial grounds for believing," "in danger of being subjected to torture," and "involuntary return" are defined in this Act as substantial evidence, circumstances where a reasonable person would fear torture, and actions leading to a person's return without consent, respectively. The United States will not forcibly return individuals to countries where they may face torture. Additionally, specific immigration procedures are in place for victims of torture. Any alien who claims to have been tortured in their country of nationality or last habitual residence and applies for refugee status, asylum, or withholding of deportation will be processed according to this section. Officials considering these applications must take into account the effects of torture. Officials processing refugee applications from individuals claiming to have been tortured must consider the impact of torture on the applicant's ability to provide information, the challenges victims face in recounting their experiences, and the fear of returning to their country where perpetrators may still hold power. Refugees with credible claims of torture are given priority in the selection process. The United States gives priority to refugees with compelling humanitarian concerns. Asylum officers can expedite asylum interviews for those at risk of torture. Parole may be granted to tortured individuals at the port of entry. The sense of Congress is that resources should be allocated to maintain information on torture in foreign countries. This information can be used as a basis for granting parole to individuals who have suffered from torture. SEC. 6. SPECIALIZED TRAINING FOR CONSULAR, IMMIGRATION, AND ASYLUM PERSONNEL. The Attorney General and the Secretary of State provide specialized training for immigration and consular officers on identifying evidence of torture, its effects, and how to interview victims without retraumatizing them. Gender-specific training is provided for interacting with male and female victims of torture by rape or sexual violence. The Center for Disease Control will conduct a study on torture victims among refugees and asylees in the US since 1987, focusing on their needs and available recovery services. A report with findings and recommendations will be submitted to Congress by December 31, 1997. Additionally, there will be a provision for domestic treatment centers. Amendment of the Immigration and Nationality Act to provide grants for services for the rehabilitation of torture victims, including treatment of physical and psychological effects, social services, and research/training for healthcare providers. The term 'torture' is defined as in the Torture Victims Relief Act of 1995. The Torture Victims Relief Act of 1995 defines 'torture' for the purposes of providing grants for services to rehabilitate torture victims. Appropriations are authorized for domestic centers treating victims of torture, with funds remaining available until expended. The effective date of the amendment is October 1, 1995. SEC. 9. FOREIGN TREATMENT CENTERS. Amendments to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 authorize the President to provide assistance for the rehabilitation of victims of torture through grants to treatment centers in foreign countries. This assistance includes direct services to victims of torture and training for healthcare providers to treat the physical and psychological effects of torture. The amendment defines 'torture' as per the Torture Victims Relief Act of 1995. It authorizes appropriations for the President to carry out section 129 of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 for fiscal year 1995, with funds remaining available until expended. The effective date of the amendment is October 1, 1995. SEC. 10. MULTILATERAL ASSISTANCE. Authorization of Appropriations for the United Nations Voluntary Fund for Victims of Torture: $1,500,000 for fiscal year 1996 and $3,000,000 for fiscal year 1997. Funds are available until expended. Congress urges the President to support treatment centers for rehabilitation. The United States aims to support treatment centers for victims of torture, develop new centers, and work with international bodies to investigate human rights violations in countries with systematic torture practices.
